title: mb-article HTML Format for Quarto
text:
Heading 2
Fonts and colors are used as expected. Further, using my own mb-tools R package, I can customize additional plot elements.

library(ggplot2)

ggplot(mtcars, aes(factor(carb), mpg, fill = factor(carb))) +
  geom_col() +
  guides(fill = guide_legend(nrow = 1)) +
  labs(
    title = "Custom ggplot with Bootstrap brand",
    subtitle = "Theme provided by R package `mblabs`",
    caption = "A long plot caption with many references
    over multiples lines."
  )




A sample dynamic graph





Heading 3
Sample paragraph content with list of items:

List 1

List 1.1
List 1.2

List 2
List 3

Ordered list:

List 1
List 2
List 3

Finally a normal rule hr element.

And a paragraph of content after the rule.

Heading 4
By default cittaions (and cross-references) are read in from an external references.bib file, but this may be edited in the YAML front matter as usual. Each citation must have a key, composed of ‘@’ + the citation identifier from the database. Here is a margin reference to (Xie 2015).

Xie, Yihui. 2015. Dynamic Documents with R and Knitr. 2nd ed. Boca Raton, Florida: Chapman; Hall/CRC. https://yihui.name/knitr/.

Heading 5
Here is a long footnote reference3. Caption and footnote placement can be controlled in the config files _quarto_yml and/or _metadata.yml, or directly in the YAML front matter.
3 Here’s a margin note with multiple paragraph blocks and a fancy section header.
Heading 5
With subsequent paragraphs indented to show that they belong to the previous footnote.
Section 6
Headers at level 6 are used as section dividers.
